Blaschke products, Schwarz lemma

Let fff be an analytic function in the open unit disc D={z∣∣z∣<1}D = \set{z \mid \abs{z} < 1}D={z∣∣z∣<1} that obeys ∣f(z)∣≤1\abs{f\p{z}} \leq 1∣f(z)∣≤1 for all z∈Dz \in Dz∈D. Let ggg be the striction of fff to the real interval (0,1)\p{0, 1}(0,1) and assume

lim⁡r→1g(r)=1andlim⁡r→1g′(r)=0.\lim_{r\to1} g\p{r} = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{r\to1} g'\p{r} = 0.r→1lim​g(r)=1andr→1lim​g′(r)=0.

Prove that fff is constant.
Solution.

If ∣f(z)∣=1\abs{f\p{z}} = 1∣f(z)∣=1 anywhere in DDD, then fff is constant by the maximum principle. Now suppose that ∣f(z)∣<1\abs{f\p{z}} < 1∣f(z)∣<1 for all z∈Dz \in Dz∈D.

If we can apply the Schwarz lemma, then we know that fff grows at most like ∣z∣\abs{z}∣z∣, which "barely" approaches 111 as r→1r \to 1r→1. But the extra decay from ∣f′(z)∣\abs{f'\p{z}}∣f′(z)∣ tending to 000 will cause fff to grow too slowly to reach 111, which will be our contradiction.

In order to apply the Schwarz lemma, we need to perform a change of variables first. Consider the Blaschke product φa ⁣:D→D\func{\phi_a}{D}{D}φa​:D→D where a∈Da \in Da∈D, given by

φa(z)=z−a1−a‾z,\phi_a\p{z} = \frac{z - a}{1 - \conj{a}z},φa​(z)=1−azz−a​,

which is a biholomorphic function. By a quick calculation, φa\phi_aφa​ has derivative

φa′(z)=1−a‾z+(z−a)a‾(1−a‾z)2=1−∣a∣2(1−a‾z)2.\phi_a'\p{z} = \frac{1 - \conj{a}z + \p{z - a}\conj{a}}{\p{1 - \conj{a}z}^2} = \frac{1 - \abs{a}^2}{\p{1 - \conj{a}z}^2}.φa′​(z)=(1−az)21−az+(z−a)a​=(1−az)21−∣a∣2​.

By assumption, ∣f(0)∣<1\abs{f\p{0}} < 1∣f(0)∣<1, so φf(0)\phi_{f\p{0}}φf(0)​ is well-defined. Moreover,

lim⁡r∈R,r→1(φf(0)∘f)(z)=lim⁡r∈R,r→1f(z)−f(0)1−f(0)‾f(z)=1−f(0)1−f(0)‾.\lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} \p{\phi_{f\p{0}} \circ f}\p{z} = \lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} \frac{f\p{z} - f\p{0}}{1 - \conj{f\p{0}}f\p{z}} = \frac{1 - f\p{0}}{1 - \conj{f\p{0}}}.r∈R,r→1lim​(φf(0)​∘f)(z)=r∈R,r→1lim​1−f(0)​f(z)f(z)−f(0)​=1−f(0)​1−f(0)​.

Hence, we may define h=eiθφf(0)∘fh = e^{i\theta}\phi_{f\p{0}} \circ fh=eiθφf(0)​∘f, where θ\thetaθ is chosen so that lim⁡r∈R,r→1h(r)=eiθφf(0)\lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} h\p{r} = e^{i\theta}\phi_{f\p{0}}limr∈R,r→1​h(r)=eiθφf(0)​. Observe that h(0)=0h\p{0} = 0h(0)=0 and that

lim⁡r∈R,r→1∣h′(r)∣=lim⁡r∈R,r→11−∣f(0)∣2∣1−f(0)‾f(r)∣2∣f′(r)∣=1−∣f(0)∣2∣1−f(0)‾∣2lim⁡r∈R,r→1∣f′(r)∣=0.\begin{aligned} \lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} \abs{h'\p{r}} &= \lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} \frac{1 - \abs{f\p{0}}^2}{\abs{1 - \conj{f\p{0}}f\p{r}}^2} \abs{f'\p{r}} \\ &= \frac{1 - \abs{f\p{0}}^2}{\abs{1 - \conj{f\p{0}}}^2} \lim_{r\in\R,r\to1} \abs{f'\p{r}} \\ &= 0. \end{aligned}r∈R,r→1lim​∣h′(r)∣​=r∈R,r→1lim​∣∣​1−f(0)​f(r)∣∣​21−∣f(0)∣2​∣f′(r)∣=∣∣​1−f(0)​∣∣​21−∣f(0)∣2​r∈R,r→1lim​∣f′(r)∣=0.​

Since φf(0)\phi_{f\p{0}}φf(0)​ has image in the disk, we still have h ⁣:D→D\func{h}{D}{D}h:D→D and so we may apply the Schwarz lemma to get ∣h(z)∣≤∣z∣\abs{h\p{z}} \leq \abs{z}∣h(z)∣≤∣z∣.

We now restrict ourselves to r∈(0,1)r \in \p{0, 1}r∈(0,1). Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. There then exists 0<δ<10 < \delta < 10<δ<1 such that if r>1−δr > 1 - \deltar>1−δ, then ∣h′(z)∣<ε\abs{h'\p{z}} < \epsilon∣h′(z)∣<ε. For these values of rrr, we have

∣h(r)∣=∣∫0rh′(t) dt∣≤∣∫01−δh′(t) dt∣+∣∫1−δrh′(t) dt∣≤∣h(1−δ)−h(0)∣+∫1−δr∣h′(t)∣ dt≤∣h(1−δ)∣+∫1−δrε dt=1−δ+ε(r−1+δ).\begin{aligned} \abs{h\p{r}} &= \abs{\int_0^r h'\p{t} \,\diff{t}} \\ &\leq \abs{\int_0^{1-\delta} h'\p{t} \,\diff{t}} + \abs{\int_{1-\delta}^r h'\p{t} \,\diff{t}} \\ &\leq \abs{h\p{1 - \delta} - h\p{0}} + \int_{1-\delta}^r \abs{h'\p{t}} \,\diff{t} \\ &\leq \abs{h\p{1 - \delta}} + \int_{1-\delta}^r \epsilon \,\diff{t} \\ &= 1 - \delta + \epsilon\p{r - 1 + \delta}. \end{aligned}∣h(r)∣​=∣∣​∫0r​h′(t)dt∣∣​≤∣∣​∫01−δ​h′(t)dt∣∣​+∣∣​∫1−δr​h′(t)dt∣∣​≤∣h(1−δ)−h(0)∣+∫1−δr​∣h′(t)∣dt≤∣h(1−δ)∣+∫1−δr​εdt=1−δ+ε(r−1+δ).​

Letting r→1r \to 1r→1, we have

1≤1−δ(1−ε).1 \leq 1 - \delta\p{1 - \epsilon}.1≤1−δ(1−ε).

In particular, if ε=12\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}ε=21​, then 1≤1−δ2<11 \leq 1 - \frac{\delta}{2} < 11≤1−2δ​<1, which is impossible. Hence, fff must have been constant to begin with.
